title: Online onsite admission test Radio Navigation v24.1

questions.query: How is the integrity of the data in the navigation database guaranteed?

options.text: There are always two, the same databases, which are constantly compared.
One pilot enters the data, the other pilot must acknowledge.
The two pilots must individually enter the data, and then compare with each other.
The flight crew cannot alter the data in the navigation database.
options.comment: Manually set as correct, might be different from source.

options.comment: Manually set as correct, might be different from source.

options.text: NAVSTAR is the Russian version of the US GPS.

options.comment: Manually set as correct, might be different from source.

options.text: Global coverage is achieved by employing a SBAS.
When flying from the West to the East, the GNSS has to switch over from GPS, via Galileo and GLONASS to BEIDOU.

options.comment: Manually set as correct, might be different from source.

options.text: electron gun in a vacuum glass tube with a rotating timebase and a green phosphoric screen.

options.text: correct for the loss of signal strenght when traveling large distances.
find turbulence by looking for fast moving targets.
detect and predict the path of a heavy rainshower.
compensate for the absorption and reflection of radar energy caused by heavy precipitation.

options.comment: Manually set as correct, might be different from source.

options.text: SSR/S is a special SSR mode with 2^12 = 4096 possible codes.
SSR/S has a datalink capability that is also used by TCAS-II.

options.text: SSR/S transmits the 3D position with a higher accuracy than SSR/AC.

GPS augmentation must improve...

  1. accuracy;
  2. integrity;
  3. availability.

The most complete answer is...

questions.query: The advantage of a GNSS receiver over a GPS receiver is...

options.text: a GNSS receiver can be used worldwide.
a GNSS receiver has a more effective RAIM (Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitoring) function.
options.comment: Manually set as correct, might be different from source.

options.text: a GNSS receiver uses two frequencies to determine the IPD (ionospheric propagation delay).

questions.query: The clock in a GPS-receiver...

options.text: needs the same accuracy as the atomic clocks in the GPS-satellites.
must be set to UTC taken from the aircraft's clock.
needs a fourth satellite to correct for errors.
options.comment: Manually set as correct, might be different from source.

questions.query: The American WAAS (Wide Area Augmentation System) can be described as...

options.text: a system that provides differential corrections and navigation signals, transmitted by geostatioanry communication satellites.
options.comment: Manually set as correct, might be different from source.

options.text: a differential station in the vicinity of the aerodrome that transmits correction signals for the pseudo ranges.
a pseudo satellite (pseudolite) just in front of the runway to enable CAT 3 operations with GPS.
the GPS control segment consisting of monitor stations, a master control station and several uplink stations.

questions.query:
The DME installation of an aircraft flying at FL430 calculates a slant range of 15 NM from a beacon with an elevation of 167 ft.

The plan range is…

 

Note: ISA condtions.
RAIM (Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitoring...

options.text: delivers integrity data to the satellite via the up-link stations after the determination of the correct ephemerides by the master control station.
monitors the satellites via the monitor-stations spread over the earth.
discovers unreliable satellites with a program in the receiver.
determines differential corrections that can be sent to the users (receivers).

questions.query: Frequency modulation is used in the...

options.text: ILS system for the modulation of the 90 and 150 Hz navigation signals.
GPS system to synchronise the satellite clock  and the receiver clock.
CVOR system for the transmission of the reference signal.

questions.query: When the depth of modulation (M) is 0%...

options.text: the amplitude of the modulating signal equals the amplitude of the carrier wave.
the ratio between the amplitude of the modulating signal and the amplitude of the carrier wave is zero.
the aircraft is on the localiser and on the glide-slope of the ILS.
the difference between the frequency of the carrier wave and the frequency of the modulating signal is zero.

questions.query:
Information can be transmitted by radio waves by...

  1. temporary interruption of the transmission;
  2. modulating the amplitude of the carrier wave;
  3. modulating the frequency of the carrier wave.
The channel spacing of a VHF-COM signal is...
FM is less sensitive to atmospheric disturbances than AM because...

options.text: FM signals are not sensitive to amplitude variations.
FM uses frequencies in excess of 30 MHz.

questions.query: Regarding amplitude modulation (AM)...

options.text: single side band (SSB) needs a smaller bandwidth than double side band (DSB).
the carrier wave is modulated on the information signal.
the larger the volume of the information signal, the larger the bandwidth.

questions.query:
Which part of the electromagnetic radiofrequency spectrum is assigned to aviation?

 

Note: Choose the most complete alternative.

options.comment: This is ‘only’ the VHF-NAV and COM band. The aviation RF band is from 3 kHz to 300 GHz.

questions.query: A radio wave is a(n)...
The propagation speed of radio waves is...

options.text: 300 000 km/h but only at 15 deg C.

questions.query: What is the advantage of FM over AM?

options.text: FM allows for voice signals to be transmitted; AM not.
FM allows double side band transmissions, AM not.
FM signals are not disturbed by atmospheric noise such as lightning strikes and P-static, AM signals are.
FM signals are not affected by the ionosphere, AM signals are.

questions.query: The photograph below shows a...

options.comment: A vertical monopole antenna; a dipole antenna would be fed from the middle.

questions.query: A vertical antenna has...

A vertical dipole antenna has a polar diagram in the shape of a...
A horizontal antenna has a...
A circular polarised antenna...

options.text: is a vertical antenna with a circular shaped polar antenna diagram.
rotates at a certain rpm to generate a certain frequency.
is also known as a helical (spiral wound) antenna.

questions.query: Why does a flat-plate, phased-array antenna result in a larger range than a parabolic-dish antenna?

options.text: A flat plate antenna can transmit more power.
A flat plate antenna has a lower pulse repetition frequency (PRF).
A flat plate antenna has less side lobes.
A flat plate antenna is not moving.

questions.query: What would be the length of a monopole antenna which is suited for 1000 MHz?
Another name for ground waves is...
Another name for space waves is...
The skip distance is the ground distance...

options.text: from the transmitter in which the ionosphere wave cannot be received.
from the transmitter in which the surface wave cannot be received.
along which the ionosphere wave can be received.
between the first and the last reflected ionsophere wave.

questions.query: An aeroplane at an altitude of 3000 ft, has a radio horizon of approximately...
At periods of super refraction...

options.text: space waves are curved towards the earth surface, resulting in an increased ground range.
sky waves are refracted by clouds of free electrons causing an increasing skip distance.
ground waves can reach further when the transmission power is increased.
direct waves are curved towards the earth surface, resulting in a decreasing the ground range.

questions.query: Radio waves that refract by the ionosphere are those with frequencies...

options.text: in the VLF, LF, MF and HF band.

questions.query: Regarding HF communication, how to increase the skip distance?
Super refraction is due to a(n)...

options.text: abnormally high ionisation density caused by more intense sun-spot activity.
high static charge of cumulonimbi caused by thunderstorms.
very high seawater surface temperature, for example in tropical coastal seas.
inversion (increasing temperature with altitude) and/or a sharp decrease of the relative humidity with altitude.

questions.query: The range of surface waves...

options.text: is higher during night due to the condition of the ionosphere.

questions.query: Regarding direction finding, a Class-C bearing is accurate within plus or minus...
VDF covers the following frequency band(s)...

options.text: transmission of a Morse code starting with the letter 'Q’.

VDF responds to the...
How does the needle of the VDF indicator responds, when the pilot only presses the push-to-talk (PTT) button?

options.text: Nothing happens until the pilot starts to talk in the microphone.
The indicator needle shows an ambiguous bearing until the pilot starts to talk in the microphone.
The indicator needle shows the bearing unambiguously.
The indicator needle goes to the parking position.

questions.query:
Air traffic control (ATC) gives the pilot a QDM of 265.

The magnetic variation is 12º W.

The QDR is...
In which of the following circumstances will VDF most likely be used to determine the position of an aircraft.

options.text: If an aircraft transmits an urgency (pan-pan) call on any frequency.
At first contact after passing the FIR boundary.
When the pilot transmits a distress call (Mayday) on 121.5 MHz.
If ATC is contacted in order to fly from an uncontrolled airspace to a controlled airspace.

questions.query: Which statement is true for an airway NDB?

options.text: The range of airway NDB's is limited to the radio horizon.
The accuracy of the line of position (LOP) received from an airway NDB is less during sunrise and sunset.
The range of an airway NDB is more than the range of a Terminal VOR.

questions.query: Which of the following statements about ADF and/or NDB is correct?

options.text: The BFO is a component of the ADF.
The only purpose of the vertical sense antenna is to enable the ADF to receive the ident.
The quadrantal error is caused by disturbances in the propagation path crossing the coast.
The frequency band is limited to 190 - 450 kHz.

questions.query: The quadrantal error of an ADF receiver is caused by...
The bearing to an NDB, taken by an ADF receiver is...

Which of the following statements regarding NDB's is correct?

  1. Locators always transmits non-directional;
  2. Radio Broadcast Stations can always be used for NBD navigation;
  3. Oceanic NDB's can never be found at land.
What is the minimum number of NDB's to take a QTF?
The NDB-bearing that is taken by an ADF receiver, is shown as a...

options.text: TB, if the ADF is connected to a gyromagnetic compass.
RB, if the bearing indicator is not connected to any compass system.
MB, independent of the used compass system.
CB, if the indicator is a fixed card indicator.

questions.query: One of the reasons for not taking bearings of (public or commercial) radio broadcast stations (RBS) is...

options.text: RBS do not transmit idents within the prescribed intervals.
RBS signals are circular polarised and therefore not suited for taking bearings.
RBS transmit FM instead of AM signals.

questions.query: The accuracy of an NDB bearing is affected by...

options.text: radio noise, Doppler effect and deviation error.
precipitation static, mountain effect and turning error.
heavy snow and rain, coastal effect and dip error.

questions.query: The transmission of an aviation NDB is...

options.text: non-directional with a range that depends on the type of beacon.
in the LF/MF band with a 1350 Hz AM Morse ident.

questions.query: Bearings from aviation NDBs are preferred over bearings from public or commercial radio broadcast stations because the...

options.text: radio broadcast stations use A3 modulated signals which are much more sensitive to disturbances than NDB signals.
position of the antenna of the broadcast station is usually unknown.

questions.query:
Given:

  • True Heading (TH) of the aircraft is 030°;
  • Relative Bearing with the ADF is 160°L;
  • Magnetic variation = 10°W;
  • Deviation = +2°.

The compass bearing on the RMI is...

options.text: a reduced transmitter power with optimum reception just above the beacon.
horizontal polarisation of the transmitted signal with a cone of confusion.
NON/A2A type of transmission in the LF/MF band.
a voice ident consisting of 3 words per minute.

questions.query: Which statement regarding the parking position of an ADF needle is correct?

options.text: The needle is at a 90 degrees RB position.

questions.query:
Given an HSI:

  • CRS at 270;
  • CDI at the left inner dot;
  • T/F at TO.

The aircraft is on radial...
The reception of a VOT will result in an RMI indication, that is...

options.text: dependent of the position of the aircraft.

questions.query:
Given:

  • an aircraft tracks radial 315° inbound to a VOR station;
  • the drift is 5°L;
  • the relative bearing of an NDB is 60°R.

The indication on the RMI will be (dev = 0)...
Which statement about CVOR and DVOR is correct?

options.text: A CVOR has a carrier wave that is AM; a DVOR has a carrier wave that is FM.
CVORS are used in terminal areas; DVOR are used at airways.
CVORs transmit in the VHF band; DVORs transmit in the UHF band.
The variable signals of CVOR and DVOR rotate in opposite directions.
options.comment:
Correct.

This is necessary to solve for the difference in REF and VAR.

VAR @ CVOR is 30 Hz AM; REF @ CVOR is 30 Hz FM

VAR @ DVOR is 30 Hz FM; REF @ DVOR is 30 Hz AM.

In the receiver the radial is -traditionally- determined by comparing 30 HZ FM (REF) - 30 Hz AM (VAR).

questions.query: A correct description of a VOT is...

options.text: A beacon that gives a certain radial that is indicated on a VOR checkpoint.
A special beacon that gives the aircraft installation the impression that the aircraft is on radial 360.
A beacon that is positioned near a terminal and that operates at reduced power.
A monitor station that monitors the VOR transmissions.

questions.query:
Given:

  • At VOR TCK (65°13.7'N, 155°21.1'W) the magnetic variation is 24°E;
  • The DR of the aircraft is (64°10.0'N, 152°25.0'W) and the magnetic variation 22°E;
  • The deviation is -1°;
  • The HSI heading is 255°;
  • The CRS is 290°;
  • The CDI is on the left inner dot.

The radial of the aircraft's position and TO/FR indication are...

Given:

  • At VOR TCK (65°13.7'N, 155°21.1'W) the magnetic variation is 24°E;
  • The DR of the aircraft is (64°10.0'N, 152°25.0'W);
  • The magnetic variation 22°E;
  • The deviation is -1°;
  • The heading on the HSI is 255°;
  • The CRS is 290° and the CDI is on the left inner dot;
  • At the moment that the TO/FR indicator changes, the course deviation bar is completely to the right.

On which radial is the aircraft at that moment?

Which of the following statements is true for a conventional airway VOR?

  1. The fixed omni-directional antenna transmits a VHF-carrier wave with the following modulations: a 30 Hz AM reference signa, and a 1020 Hz AM Ident.
  2. The rotating directional antenna transmits a VHF-carrier wave with a 30 Hz FM variable signal.

options.comment: Both statements are false: the fixed antenna is 30 Hz FM, rotating antenna is 30 Hz AM.

questions.query: The difference between CVOR and TVOR is...

options.text: A CVOR transmits omni-directional 360 radials; a TVOR transmits non-directional 1 radial.
A TVOR sets the limits of TMA's; a CVOR sets the limits of CTA's.
A TVOR is a low power CVOR situated near aerodromes.
A CVOR is used in combination with ILS; a TVOR is used in combination with MLS.

questions.query: Which statement regarding VOR is correct?

options.text: The wave length of a CVOR is larger than that of a DVOR.
A DVOR is less sensitive to ionospheric reflections than a TVOR.
The reference for a CVOR is compass North and for a TVOR true North.
A TVOR is used for terminal navigation and a VOT is used for test purposes.

questions.query: Which statement is true regarding an early-type VOR-indicator (OBI)?

options.text: A full scale deflection of the needle indicates an angular displacement of 2.5°.
options.comment: This depends on the setting of the OBS: when the aircraft flies radial 090 outbond while the OBS is set to 270, the T/F indicator shows TO.

options.text: To maintain the 'follow the needle' principle, the 'course pointer' must be set in the direction of the radial to be flown.
Above a VOR beacon, the indication of the RMI is reliable.
A FROM indication is given as soon as the aircraft starts to fly an outbound radial.

questions.query: Which two-statement answer regarding VOR is true?

options.text: The range is line-of-sight, and the transmission frequency is in the UHF-band.
The capacity of the system is unlimited, and there is no ambiguity.
options.comment:
Correct.

Unlike DME, VOR has no limit in capacity.

Ambiguity, if any, is solved by the T/F indicator.

options.text: The line-of-position is a radial, and the accuracy of a CVOR and a DVOR are equal.
A full-scale-deflection is five degrees, and the transmission power is the same for all kinds of VOR stations.

questions.query: System- or beacon saturation of the DME system...

options.text: occurs when the flight crew forgets to select the DME from the 'search mode' to the 'standby mode'.
can be avoided by increasing the station delay time from 50 to150 microseconds.
is solved by introducing X- and Y-channels, resulting in 252 available interrogation frequencies.
occurs when more than 90 aircraft are demanding replies from one single ground station.

questions.query: Which statement about DME squitter pulses is true?

options.text: Squitter pulses prevent the DME from overloading when the maximum amount of aircraft is reached.
Squitter pulses are pulses that are reflected by objects between ground and aircraft.
Squitter pulses are transmitted from the interrogator in the 'search' mode.
Squitter pulses are transmitted by the ground station to makes sure the constant duty cycle is maintained.

questions.query: The reason for using X- and Y-channels within DME is...

options.text: to have more channels avaliable than the numer of frequencies.
to have X-channels in the VHF-band and Y-channels in the UHF-band.
to distinct between an interrogation signal and a reply signal on the same frequency.
to assign X-channels to civil users and Y-channels to military users.

questions.query: An ILS-DME is tuned by selecting on the NAV control panel the appropriate...
The DME slant range correction is automatically applied...

options.text: when connecting the DME receiver to the encoding altimeter.
when the distance is more than five times the altitude.
in the Flight Management System (FMS) of a large aircraft.

questions.query: Which statement about rho-theta navigation is correct?

options.text: The capacity of the VOR is unlimited, the capacity of the DME is limited to about 100 aircraft.
A VORTAC gives direction information only to civil users.

questions.query: When the plan range between a DME interrogator at FL350, and a transponder at SL is 200 NM, the calculated slant range is...

options.text: not possible as this distance exceeds the designated operational coverage (DOC) range of the DME.

questions.query: The slant range correction for an aircraft flying at FL300 with a DME reading of 100 NM is...
Which statement about DME is true?

options.text: DME has X- and Y-channels in order to create the possibility to use the same DME frequency for two DME stations.
When a DME changes over from the 'tracking mode' to the 'memory mode', the interrogation frequency increases.
In case of an ILS/DME, the DME frequency has to be selected separately by the pilot.
The accuracy of a DME/N and a DME/P are equal.
The Station Dead (or recovery) time accounts for the internal delay in the processing of the signal.
The transponder determines the slant range by measuring the spacing between two pulse pairs and transmits this to the aircraft.
The interrogator enters the search mode if squitter pulses are received.
In the standby mode the PRF is reduced to 30 pps to avoid beacon saturation.

questions.query: The DME installation of an aircraft flying at FL430 calculates a slant range of 15 NM from a beacon with an elevation of 167 ft. The plan range is&he...

Which of the following DME statements is correct?

  1. Multipath protection is done in the aircraft as well as in the ground station.
  2. Loss of reply signals may be caused as a result of the constant duty cycle.

An aircraft flies outbound from a VOR/DME station and crosses the border of the designated operational coverage area.

As soon as the DME-signal is no longer received, the DME interrogator will...

options.text: immediately switch to the 'search mode' and start to interrogate with maximum 150 pp/second.
in case of a 'static memory' show the last determined slant range for about 10 seconds, before switching back to the 'auto standby' mode.
interrogate in the 'tracking mode' with a maximum of 30 pp/second until another station is tuned.

questions.query: The constant duty cycle of a DME...

options.text: is a system in which the gain of the ground based receiver gain is varied in such a way that the 90-100 strongest signals are answered.
lets the airborne based interrogator transmit squitter pulses when there is no contact with a ground station.
makes sure DME channels are paired to VOR frequencies.

questions.query:
On an ILS approach chart, there is a table that shows the required 'rate-of-descent' for a number of groundspeeds in order to fly a certain glidepath.

Under which conditions can the DME groundspeed read-out be used for this purpose?

  1. ILS/DME abeam the touch down zone;
  2. VOR/DME within 5 NM in front of the runway;
  3. TACAN within 5 NM from the airport;
  4. VORTAC 5 NM behind the runway.
A false glideslope of an ILS is the result of...

options.text: beam bends caused by large metal surfaces in the vicinity of the ILS.
atmospheric disturbances such as heavy precipitation and thunderstorms.

questions.query: The ILS critical area is...

options.text: situated in front of the Localizer and Glide path antenna; in this area no large craft are allowed during Cat-II or Cat-III approaches.
an area around the runway where no vehicles are allowed to drive, in order to keep a safe distance to landing aircraft.
an area around the LLZ as well as the GP antenna, in which the presence of aircraft or other craft causes disturbances of the ILS signal.
for an approaching B747 aircraft much larger than for a Diamond Twinstar.

questions.query: The blue outer marker signal of the ILS is...
The minimum range of the ILS localiser transmitter is...

options.text: 25 NM in a sector 17° to both sides of the centreline.
40 NM to an elevation of 1.75 times the glide path angle.
25 NM in a sector of 10° and 17 NM in a sector of 35° on both sides of the centreline.

questions.query: The ILS receiver has an AM detector behind its VHF filter in order to demodulate the...

options.text: 90 Hz and the 150 Hz signal on the glide path carrier.
transmitted DDM of the marker beacon beacon.
identification and navigation signals of the localiser transmission.

questions.query: The transmission of the ILS glidepath beacon is characterised by a...

options.text: VHF frequency modulated carrier wave with a 90 Hz AM and a 150 Hz AM navigation signal.
UHF frequency with a minimum range of 10 NM.
series of two 30 Hz signals of which the difference in depth of modulation is measured.

questions.query: Which of the following statements regarding Marker Beacons is true?

options.text: MBs frequencies are paired to the GP frequency.
The Outer Marker is usually passed at a height of about 1200 ft.

questions.query: Whn flying a 3° glide path with a groundspeed of 100 kt, the rate-of-descent is...
The wave length of the Marker Beacon transmission is...
Beam bends are...

options.text: slight curves in the ILS radio signals that can be followed by large aircraft.
curves in the GP signal that are visible on the indicator, but change too fast to be followed by a large aircraft.
curves that are part of the normal LOC approach procedure because of 'noise abatement'.
curved approaches that are made with the aid of the microwave landing system.

questions.query: Which statement is correct for an ILS?

options.text: The accuracy of the localizer- and the glide slope-beam is the same for all ILS categories.
Every ILS has three marker beacon-, two localizer- and two glidepath transmitters.
ILS integrity monitoring is a function of the aircraft installation.
The range of an ILS is according the 'line of sight' principle.

questions.query: Which statement for airborne ILS instrumentation is true?

options.text: A filter behind the UHF-receiver demodulates the 90 and 150 Hz signals of the localizer beacon.
The DME-part of an ILS must be manually tuned.
Marker beacons are received with the UHF-receivers
When there are no modulation components on the carries, the DDM is zero and there wil be a flag warning.
options.comment:
When the two modulation components of either LOC or GP are present, and the DDM is zero, the associated deviation bar is centred.

When there are no modulation components, the DDM is also zero and only then there will be a flag warning.

questions.query: The operational capacity of an ILS is limited by...

options.text: the ILS facility performance: a CAT 3 ILS can handle more aircraft than a CAT 1/2 ILS.

questions.query:
Given an ILS-DME approach.

Three-dimensional guidance to the runway-threshold can be expected from a distance of...
Regarding ILS, when the DDM is zero...

An aircraft is on an ILS approach.

When the aircraft is right of the localiser centerline and above the glide path, it can be stated that…

 

Note:

Always look in the direction of flight.

options.text:
the 150 Hz LOC signal is weaker than the 90 Hz LOC signal, and

the 150 Hz GP signal is weaker than the 90 Hz GP signal.

the 150 Hz LOC signal is stronger than the 90 Hz LOC signal, and

the 150 Hz GP signal is stronger than the 90 Hz GP signal.

the 150 Hz LOC signal is weaker than the 90 Hz LOC signal, and

the 150 Hz GP signal is stronger than the 90 Hz GP signal.

the 150 Hz LOC signal is stronger than the 90 Hz LOC signal, and

the 150 Hz GP signal is weaker than the 90 Hz GP signal.

questions.query: The DME/P that is associated with MLS, transmits...

options.text: directionally in the direction of the (extended) centerline.

questions.query: When comparing with a standard ILS-DME, a standard MLS has...

options.text: more channels and is less sensitive to multipath.

questions.query: The frequency band in which MLS operates is...
Which statement about MLS is true?

options.text: MLS has the same number of channels as ILS.
The facility performance categories are more stringent for MLS than for ILS.
The azimuth coverage is in principle 40° on either side of the centerline.
For 3-D positioning, distance information from a DME/N is used.
The time referenced scanning beams move at 5 GHz.
MLS works with pulse pairs that measure time differences.
The MLS coverage area is a circle with a radius of 20 NM.
MLS operates in the SHF band with non-moving, phased array (flat plate) antennas.

questions.query: The total sector angle of the required coverage of the MLS azimuth antenna is...
The coverage angle of the MLS EL antenna is between...

options.comment: MLS EL coverage angle is between 1 and 15 degrees.

questions.query: The MLS ident is supplied...

options.text: as a pre-amble to the AZ datablock.
as a pre-amble to the EL datablock.

questions.query: Compared to ILS, MLS has the advantage of...

options.text: far less sensitive to multipath and weather.

questions.query: MLS operates on [frequency] which is in the [band].

options.text: 1000 MHz which is in the UHF band.
108 - 112 MHz which is in the VHF band.
5 GHz which is in the SHF band.
9375 MHz which is in the SHF band.

questions.query: MLS measures distance by...

options.text: measuring the time taken for a primary radar pulse to travel from the MLS transmitter to the aircraft and back.
measuring the time taken for a secondary radar pulse to travel from the MLS transmitter to the aircraft receiver.
time measurement between a ground-based interrogator and airborne transponder.

questions.query: During periods of super-refraction, radar pulses are...

options.text: scattered, loosing too much energy for a reliable return.
traveling further causing problems with the timing of the reply pulses.
attracted by the earth's surface thereby reducing their maximum range.
absorbed by the presence of moisture in the lower part of the atmosphere.

questions.query: The azimuth resolution of radar is...

options.text: independent of the frequency of the carrier wave.

questions.query:
A pulse radar has the following data:

  • frequency 10 GHz;
  • pulse length 1 micro-second;
  • pulse interval 1235 micro-second;
  • antenna diameter 0.7 m.

For this radar it can be stated that the...

options.text: The maximum range is, amongst others, determined by the amount of pulses that is transmitted per second.

The azimuth resolution is limited by the pulse duration.

questions.query:

A radar operates on a frequency of 10 GHz with a pulse duration of 0.5 µsec.

 

How many periods does one pulse contains?
The azimuth resolution of a primary radar installation is improved by...

options.text: the pulse repetion frequency: the higher the PRF, the better the Az resolution.
the RPM of the antenna: the lower the rpm, the better the Az resolution.
the beam width: the smaller the beamwidth, the better the Az resolution.
the pulse length of the transmitted pulses: the smaller the PL, the better the Az resolution.

questions.query: The azimuth resolution of radar is improved when...

options.text:
the antenna rotates faster.

dependent of the antenna diameter and independent of the frequency.

questions.query: Which statement regarding ground radar in aviation is correct?

options.text: Ground radar can be a primary radar or a secondary radar.
Ground radar can be a pulse radar or a continuous wave radar.
Ground radar can be an interrogator or a transponder.
Ground radar can have a stationary antenna or a rotating antenna.

questions.query: A ground radar...

options.text: has a smaller range than an airborne radar because of ground reflections.

options.comment:
Correct.

The antenna is always on the ground.

questions.query: Regarding radar, a RSR is used by ATC for...

options.text: informs tower and approach controllers about the actual weather situation.
allows for circumferential navigation inside the TMA by means of radar vectors.
gives horizontal and vertical guidance into a runway.
supplies ground controllers with traffic information on airports.

questions.query: The antenna of the Surface Movement Radar (SMR) rotates at a high rpm in order to...

options.text: get a very sharp and detailed image.
compensate for the long pulse and low PRF.
refresh the actual position information of relatively fast moving objects.
create a small beam with a high azimuth (or bearing) resolution.

pulse pairs in a random order to allow lock-on on its own replies.
pulses of a constant frequency, amplitude, width and rate.

questions.query: Concerning a weather radar display, what is meant with a ‘shadow area’?

options.text: A black area behind a very heavy rainshower.

A black area beyond the maximum calibrated range.

options.text: airborne antennas to interrogate the transponders of other aircraft.
metallic parts in the aircraft construction as a back-up for the PSR.
a ground based transmit/receive antenna and an airborne receive/transmit antenna.

options.text: no ambiguity, larger range, no ground reflections, no rain targets.
cheaper, no need for transponder, less fruiting & garbling.
better radar resolution rectangle, 7777 codes instead of 4096, more sensitive antenna.
fixed (non-moving) flat plate antenna, mono (single) pulses instead of pulse pairs, larger wave length.

questions.query: The coded transmission of a SSR transponder makes use of...

options.comment:
Wrong.

The reply pulses have the same width/lenght/duration; they only change position.

A Mode-S interrogation requests the...

options.text: Special Position Identifier (SPI) or just ‘Ident’ pulse to be transmitted.

transmission of information from secondary radars only.

options.text: In Mode-C, the pressure altitude is transmitted in 50 ft increments which means the altitude can be read within 100 ft.
options.comment:
Wrong.

The other way around: 100 ft increments and readable within 50 ft.

options.text: The Special Position Identification (SPI) pulse is transmitted automatically, and independent of the interrogation signal.
Secondary radar uses a single-pulse whose amplitude is a measure for the type of interrogation.
The ‘reply’ lamp is on when the transponder is transmitting.

questions.query: Amongst others, one of the advantages of secondary radar compared to primary radar is...

options.text: aircraft can interrogate other aircraft for collision avoidance.
only one frequency is required for both interrogation and reply.

options.text: the difference in time between the two interrogation pulses.
the difference in frequency between the two interrogation pulses.
the difference in amplitude between the two interrogation pulses.
the difference in pulse length between the two interrogation pulses.

.

A mode-S transponder in ACS reports altitude in 12.5 ft increments.

questions.query: Within Mode-S, each aircraft can be identified by...
GPS uses two transmission frequencies because...

options.text: redundancy: in case of failure of one frequency, you can use the other one.
with two frequencies, the tropospheric delay can be determined.
it enables P-code receivers to determine the ionospheric delay.
from the difference in arrival time of the signal, the receiver clock error is calculated.
options.comment: The receiver clock error cannot be determined by measuring differences in time of arrival.

options.text: accuracy, availability and integrity.
sensitivity, availability and monitoring.

questions.query:

  1. are below the five degrees elevation mask angle;
  2. are within five degrees relative bearing from each other;
  3. have the same polarisation;
  4. are in one plane.
The working principle of GPS is...

options.text: to measure the travel time of a coded signal transmitted from the satellite.
to obtain the frequency shift of the 1575 MHz carrier wave by the Doppler effect.
to determine the position of four SV's by decoding the navigation message.
to interrogate the SV and wait for a reply. The runtime is a measure for the distance.

questions.query: GPS-NAVSTAR is...

options.text: The PPS allows for the reception of two frequencies to estimate the tropospheric delay.
The duration of a complete cycle of the P-code is 1 microsecond.
The C/A-code is encrypted in a Y-code.
In the SPS (Standard Position Service), use is made of only one frequency.
options.comment:
Correct.

The SPS transmits on the L1 frequency only (1575 MHz).

questions.query: The GPS receiver identifies a certain GPS-satellite by...

options.comment:
Correct.

The C/A code is the unique one millisec code.

questions.query: The navigation message of a GPS-satellite contains information about the...

options.text:
position: accurate 3D position,

velocity: groundspeed and true airspeed,

path: track and heading,

time: UTC and local time.

options.text: takes 12.5 minutes to download the first time.
only gives data regarding that one satellite.

questions.query: The geostationary communication satellites of Inmarsat augment GPS by, amongst others, transmitting 'GPS ranging signals' which will...

options.text: improve the position dilution of precision (PDOP) at latitudes < 60°.
options.comment:
Correct.

As Inmarsat is geostationary above the equator.

options.text: improve the vertical dilution of precision (VDOP) at latitudes > 60°.

questions.query: In a GBAS the VHF Data Block (VDB) supplies the aircraft with approach data plus...

options.text: corrections and integrity information for GNSS satellites in view.
meteorological information such as visibility, wind, pressure and temperature.
operational information about possible beam bends, scalloping and noise.
an update about the current weather prevailing at the airport including possible windshear.

questions.query: The principle of GBAS is...

options.text: to measure on the ground the signal errors in the signals transmitted by GNSS satellites and relay the measured errors to the user for correction.
to measure in the aircraft the signal errors in the signals transmitted by GNSS satellites and relay the measured errors to the ground for correction.
to measure in the aircraft the signal errors in the signals transmitted from the user and relay the measured errors to the GNSS for correction.
to measure on the ground the signal errors in the user and relay the measured errors to the GNSS satellites for correction.
options.comment: Just the other way around: to measure on the ground the signal errors in the signals transmitted by GNSS satellites and relay the measured errors to the user for correction.

questions.query: RAIM (Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitoring) is a technique inside the GPS-receiver to determine...

In GBAS, use can be made of ground-based pseudo satellites (pseudolites) to improve the vertical dilution of precision (VDOP).

These pseudolites...

options.text: transmit their signal via a space-based satellite.
have no 'ionospheric propagation delay' in the measured range.
suffer from the 5 degrees elevation mask angle.

questions.query: What is a 'Pseudolite'?

options.text: A GPS satellite that transmits corrupt data not suitable for positioning.
A GPS satellite that transmits a pseudo random noise code which allows for the determination of the pseudo range because the clock error is not known.
A ground based transmitter that transmits a specific C/A code including navigation information on the L1 frequency.
A communication satellite that transmits, amongst others, 'integrity messages' for GPS.

questions.query: EGNOS improves GPS accuracy by...

options.text: transmitting differential corrections via a local VHF datalink.
offering an extra satellite navigation system for position fixing.
offering an extra ranging capability for a more optimum DOP.
options.comment:
Correct.

Apart from this EGNOS also offers differential corrections in a wide area (Europe).

questions.query: In a WAAS (Wide Area Augmentation System)...

options.text: differential corrections are transmitted by other satellites using an HF-datalink.
position-dependent corrections on the ranges are transmitted.

questions.query:

  1. Multipath-effects are avoided by using a double antenna set.

Differential GPS is an application that...

options.text: compares the reception of a double GPS installation in the aircraft to measure aircraft attitude.
determines the errors in the pseudo ranges within a limited area.
determines the position by measuring the differences in the pseudo ranges of the different satellites.
derives the changes in the runtime measurement to calculate the three dimensional velocity vector.

RNP APCH is for non-controlled airfields;

RNP APCH does not need specific prior approval;

RNP AR APCH needs specific prior approval.

options.text: a percentage of the flight time in which the aircraft should fulfil to the required accuracy.

options.text: is a lateral flight path to a fix or an altitude.

options.text: a path from a fix to an altitude

questions.query: What is the difference between the path terminators TF and CF?

options.text: TF is a time to a fix; CF is a course to a fix.
TF is a track from one fix to another fix; CF is a course to a fix.
TF is a time to a fix; CF is a circle to a fix.

options.text: An offset flight path is used to enable parallel approaches.
An offset flight path is used to define the outbound track of a holding.

BB193

options.comment: Pilot cannot detect and correct for the PDE.

questions.query:
JW193

  1. the human pilot;
  2. the automatic pilot.

options.text: the co-pilot reading and recalling the barometric altimeter.
